title: 60th (2/2nd London) Division
text:
The 60th (2/2nd London) Division was an <a href="infantry">infantry</a> <a href="Division%20%28military%29">division</a> of the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> raised during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. It was the second line-formation of the <a href="47th%20%281/2nd%20London%29%20Division">47th (1/2nd London) Division</a>, and was the second of two such <a href="Territorial%20Force">Territorial Force</a> divisions formed from the surplus of London recruits in 1914.
The divisional insignia was a <a href="bee">bee</a>.
Role.
At first the division, headquartered at <a href="Sutton%20Veny">Sutton Veny</a>, Wiltshire, merely supplied the first-line Territorial divisions with drafts to replace losses through casualties. In late 1915 the division began to be equipped for field operations although it was not sent to France until July 1916, after 88 trains had conveyed the men to Southampton from camps around Warminster, Heytesbury, and Codford stations.
Its engagements included the <a href="Third%20Battle%20of%20Gaza">Third Battle of Gaza</a>, the <a href="Battle%20of%20Beersheba%20%281917%29">Battle of Beersheba (1917)</a>, the <a href="Battle%20of%20Jerusalem%20%281917%29">Battle of Jerusalem (1917)</a>, the <a href="Second%20Transjordan%20attack%20on%20Shunet%20Nimrin%20and%20Es%20Salt%20%281918%29">Second Transjordan attack on Shunet Nimrin and Es Salt (1918)</a>, the <a href="Battle%20of%20Megiddo%20%281918%29">Battle of Megiddo (1918)</a>, the <a href="Battle%20of%20Sharon%20%281918%29">Battle of Sharon (1918)</a>, and the <a href="Battle%20of%20Nahr%20el%20Faliq">Battle of Nahr el Faliq</a>.
As a "lesser" division it was sent to the minor fronts of <a href="Salonika">Salonika</a> and finally <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a>. In mid-1918, most of its British battalions were replaced with Indian battalions and sent to the <a href="Western%20Front%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Western Front</a>, the division effectively becoming a <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a> division.
Order of Battle.
The division had the following composition:
"In Britain and France"
Before leaving for Macedonia the 18-pounder batteries reverted to four-gun establishment: A/CCC Bty was reformed from its original two sections and one from B/CCC; B/CCC Bty was reformed from the other section and those of C/CCC. A/CCC Battery then joined <a href="5th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">5th Division</a> and B/CCC Bty became an instructional battery at <a href="First%20Army%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">First Army School</a>.
"In Macedonia, Egypt and Palestine"
On arrival in Macedonia the HT companies became the Wheeled Echelon and a Pack Echelon was formed on 27 October 1916; merged back into the wheeled echelon June 1917 in Egypt):
